member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Collections.ListBase
member.summary: Represents any type of list.

note.para: There are 3 ways to access or modify the items of the list: If you want all verifications to be done, use the List* methods. To bypass the fixed size and readonly verifications, use the Internal* methods. If you do not want to On* methods to be called and you also want to bypass the fixed size and readonly verifications, then use the Array* methods.
When you derive from this class you must call List* for all typed IList implementations.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Exceptions.ExceptionFilter
member.summary: Exposes utility methods for filtering exceptions.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Exceptions.ExceptionFilter.IsPublicException(System.Exception)
member.summary: Determines if an exception can be thrown by a public method.
member.param: The exception to evaluate.
member.returns: true if the exception can be thrown as-is; false if the exception should be converted.
member.remarks: Every public method should have a final exception handler for any un-caught exceptions that should call this method to determine if the exception can be thrown as-is to the caller (i.e. if the exception makes sense to the caller), or if it should be wrapped in a more meaningful exception for the caller.

member.summary: Creates a new instance of the class by opening a PFX file and retrieving the first certificate from it.
member.param: The full path to the PFX file.
The password used to encrypt the private key.
member.returns: One of the certificates in the PFX file.
member.exception: or is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An error occurs while loading certificates from the specified file.
is invalid.
member.remarks: Warning: this method returns the first Certificate it can find in the specified PFX file. Care should be taken to verify whether the correct Certificate instance is returned when using PFX files that contain more than one certificate. For more fine-grained control over which certificate is returned, use the CertificateStore.CreateFromPfxFile method to instantiate a CertificateStore object and then use the CertificateStore.FindCertificateBy*** methods.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.Certificate.DecodeExtension(Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.Extension,System.Int32,System.Type)
member.summary: Decodes the specified extension and returns an object of the specified type that is instantiated with the decoded bytes.
member.param: The certificate extension to decode.
One of the predefined constants specified in the Win32 CryptoAPI. Refer to the documentation of the CryptDecodeObject function for more information.
A instance. See remarks.
member.returns: An object of the type .

remarks.p: The specified type should have a public constructor that takes an IntPtr and an int as parameters [in that order]. The IntPtr is a pointer to the decoded buffer and the int contains the number of decoded bytes. The type should not keep the IntPtr reference after construction of an instance, because the memory is freed when the DecodeExtension method returns.

member.exception: One of the parameters is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An error occurs while decoding the certificate extension.

remarks.p: If the system store name provided in this parameter is not the name of an existing system store, a new system store will be created and used.

Some example system stores are listed in the following table.
Predefined system store name Meaning
"CA" Certification authority certificates.
"MY" A certificate store holding "My" certificates with their associated private keys.
"ROOT" Root certificates.
"SPC" Software publisher certificates.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus
member.summary: Defines the different certificate status values.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.ValidCertificate
member.summary: The certificate is valid.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.Expired
member.summary: A required certificate is not within its validity period.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidBasicConstraints
member.summary: The certificate's basic constraints are invalid or missing.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidChain
member.summary: A chain of certificates was not correctly created.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidNesting
member.summary: The validity periods of the certification chain do not nest correctly.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidPurpose
member.summary: A certificate is being used for a non permitted purpose.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidRole
member.summary: A certificate that can only be used as an end-entity is being used as a CA or visa versa.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.InvalidSignature
member.summary: The signature of the certificate cannot be verified.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.NoCNMatch
member.summary: The certificate's CN name does not match the passed value.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.ParentRevoked
member.summary: A certificate in the chain has been explicitly revoked by its issuer.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.RevocationFailure
member.summary: The revocation process could not continue. The certificates could not be checked.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.RevocationServerOffline
member.summary: Since the revocation server was offline, the called function was not able to complete the revocation check.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.Revoked
member.summary: The certificate or signature has been revoked.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.UntrustedRoot
member.summary: A certification chain processed correctly but terminated in a root certificate not trusted by the trust provider.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.UntrustedTestRoot
member.summary: The root certificate is a testing certificate and policy settings disallow test certificates.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.WrongUsage
member.summary: The certificate is not valid for the requested usage.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStatus.OtherError
member.summary: The certificate is invalid.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStoreType
member.summary: Defines the different certificate store values.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStoreType.SerializedStore
member.summary: The certificate store should be saved as a serializes store.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateStoreType.Pkcs7Message
member.summary: The certificate store should be saved as a signed PKCS7 message.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions
member.summary: Defines additional options for building a certificate chain.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.Default
member.summary: The default chain options

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckEndCert
member.summary: Revocation checking is done on the end certificate and only the end certificate.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckChain
member.summary: Revocation checking is done on all of the certificates in every chain.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckChainExcludeRoot
member.summary: Revocation checking in done on all certificates in all of the chains except the root certificate.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCacheEndCert
member.summary: When this flag is set, the end certificate is cached, which might speed up the chain-building process. By default, the end certificate is not cached and it would need to be verified each time a chain is built for it.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.RevocationCheckCacheOnly
member.summary: Revocation checking only accesses cached URLs and does not hit the wire to do any revocation URL retrieval. Supported on Windows Me, Windows 2000 and later.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.CacheOnlyUrlRetrieval
member.summary: Uses only cached URLs in building a certificate chain. The Internet and Intranet are not searched for URL-based objects. Note, not applicable to revocation checking. Set CERT_CHAIN_REVOCATION_CHECK_CACHE_ONLY to use only cached URLs for revocation checking.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.DisablePass1QualityFiltering
member.summary: For performance reasons, the second pass of chain building only considers potential chain paths that have quality greater than or equal to the highest quality determined during the first pass. The first pass only considers valid signature, complete chain and trusted roots to calculate chain quality. This flag can be set to disable this optimization and consider all potential chain paths during the second pass.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.ReturnLowerQualityContexts
member.summary: The default is to return only the highest quality chain path. Setting this flag will return the lower quality chains. These are returned in the chain context's cLowerQualityChainContext and rgpLowerQualityChainContext fields.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Certificates.CertificateChainOptions.DisableAuthRootAutoUpdate
member.summary: Setting this flag inhibits the auto update of third party roots from the Windows Update Web Server.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged
member.summary: Accesses the managed version of the ARCFour algorithm. This class cannot be inherited. ARCFour is fully compatible with the RC4TM algorithm.
member.remarks: RC4 is a trademark of RSA Data Security Inc.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4
member.summary: Represents the base class from which all implementations of the RC4 symmetric stream cipher must inherit.
member.remarks: RC4 is a trademark of RSA Data Security Inc.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the RC4 class.
member.remarks: The default keysize is 128 bits.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GenerateIV
member.summary: This is a stub method.
member.remarks: Since the RC4 cipher doesn't use an Initialization Vector, this method will not do anything.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GenerateKey
member.summary: Generates a random Key to be used for the algorithm.
member.remarks: Use this method to generate a random key when none is specified.

member.summary: Creates an instance of the default cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.
member.returns: The instance of a cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.

member.summary: Creates an instance of the specified cryptographic object used to perform the RC4 transformation.
member.param: The name of the specific implementation of to create.
member.returns: A cryptographic object.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.GetRNGCSP
member.summary: Returns an instance.
member.returns: An RNGCryptoServiceProvider instance.

member.name: F:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.m_RNG
member.summary: Holds the RNGCryptoServiceProvider object.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The block size of RC4 is always 8 bits.
member.exception: The block size is invalid.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.FeedbackSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the feedback size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: This property always throws a .
member.exception: This exception is always thrown.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the FeedbackSize property.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: This property always returns a byte array of length one. The value of the byte in the array is always set to zero.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid instance.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the IV property, however the property accepts IV's of up to one byte (RC4's ) in order to interoperate with software that has been written with the use of block ciphers in mind.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalBlockSizes
member.summary: Gets the block sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the block sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only a block size of one byte is supported by the RC4 algorithm.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.LegalKeySizes
member.summary: Gets the key sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the key sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only key sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.remarks: RC4 only supports the OFB cipher mode. See for a description of this mode.
member.exception: The cipher mode is not OFB.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm. This property always returns PaddingMode.None.
member.exception: The padding mode is set to a padding mode other than PaddingMode.None.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.ARCFourManaged.#ctor
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the ARCFourManaged class.
member.remarks: The default keysize is 128 bits.

This parameter is not used an should be set to a null reference, or to an array with zero or one bytes.
member.returns: A symmetric ARCFour decryptor object.
member.remarks: This method decrypts an encrypted message created using the overload with the same signature.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider
member.summary:
The DataProtectionCryptoServiceProvider is a class that performs encryption and decryption on data without explicitly requiring a password.
There are two different types of encryption. The first type will associate the encrypted data with the logon credentials of the current user. Hence only a user with matching logon credentials can decrypt the data.
The second type will associate the encrypted data with the local machine. Any user of a specific machine will be able to decrypt encrypted data under this scheme.
This class cannot be inherited.

member.remarks: The same entropy must be provided during the encryption and decryption process. Otherwise, the decryption will fail.

member.returns: An array of encrypted bytes.
member.remarks: The number of the returned bytes will be larger than the number of input bytes. The method will use the entropy from the property.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RC4CryptoServiceProvider.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: This property always returns a byte array of length one. The value of the byte in the array is always set to zero.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid instance.
member.remarks: RC4 doesn't use the IV property, however the property accepts IV's of up to one byte (RC4's ) in order to interoperate with software that has been written with the use of block ciphers in mind.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.BlockSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the block size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The block size in bits.
member.exception: The block size is invalid.
member.remarks: The block size is the basic unit of data that can be encrypted or decrypted in one operation. Messages longer than the block size are handled as successive blocks; messages shorter than the block size must be padded with extra bits to reach the size of a block. Valid block sizes are determined by the symmetric algorithm used.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.FeedbackSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the feedback size of the cryptographic operation in bits.
member.value: The feedback size in bits.
member.exception: The feedback size is larger than the block size.
member.remarks: The feedback size determines the amount of data that is fed back to successive encryption or decryption operations. The feedback size cannot be greater than the block size.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.IV
member.summary: Gets or sets the initialization vector (IV) for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The initialization vector.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the IV to a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An attempt is made to set the IV to an invalid size.
member.remarks: If this property is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) when it is used, is called to create a new random value.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Key
member.summary: Gets or sets the secret key for the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The secret key to be used for the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: An attempt is made to set the key to a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).

remarks.p: The secret key is used both for encryption and for decryption. For a symmetric algorithm to be secure, the secret key must be known only to the sender and the receiver. The valid key sizes are specified by the particular symmetric algorithm implementation and are listed in .
If this property is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic) when it is used, is called to create a new random value.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.KeySize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the secret key used by the symmetric algorithm in bits.
member.value: The size of the secret key used by the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: The key size is not valid.
member.remarks: The valid key sizes are specified by the particular symmetric algorithm implementation and are listed in .

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.LegalBlockSizes
member.summary: Gets the block sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the block sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only block sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.LegalKeySizes
member.summary: Gets the key sizes that are supported by the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: An array containing the key sizes supported by the algorithm.
member.remarks: Only key sizes that match an entry in this array are supported by the symmetric algorithm.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Mode
member.summary: Gets or sets the mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The mode for operation of the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: The cipher mode is not one of the CipherMode values.
member.remarks: See CipherMode for a description of specific modes.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Cryptography.RijndaelCryptoServiceProvider.Padding
member.summary: Gets or sets the padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.value: The padding mode used in the symmetric algorithm.
member.exception: The padding mode is not one of the PaddingMode values.
member.remarks: Most plain text messages do not consist of a number of bytes that completely fill blocks. Often, there are not enough bytes to fill the last block. When this happens, a padding string is added to the text. For example, if the block length is 64 bits and the last block contains only 40 bits, 24 bits of padding are added. See for a description of specific modes.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureSocket
member.summary: Implements the Berkeley sockets interface and optionally encrypts/decrypts transmitted data.
member.remarks: Any public static (Shared in Visual Basic) members of this type are safe for multithreaded operations. Any instance members are not guaranteed to be thread safe.

member.name: T:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket
member.summary: Implements the Berkeley sockets interface.
member.remarks: The VirtualSocket class implements exactly the same methods as the System.Net.Sockets.Socket class, however all these methods are marked as virtual so they can be overridden in derived classes. In addition to the constructor specified by the Socket class, the VirtualSocket class also has a constructor that accepts an already created Socket; this can be very useful is you have to override the Accept and BeginAccept/EndAccept methods in a derived class.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.#ctor(System.Net.Sockets.AddressFamily,System.Net.Sockets.SocketType,System.Net.Sockets.ProtocolType)
member.summary: Initializes a new instance of the VirtualSocket class.
member.param: One of the values.
One of the values.
One of the values.
member.exception: The combination of , , and results in an invalid socket.
member.remarks:
The parameter specifies the addressing scheme that the VirtualSocket uses, the parameter specifies the type of the VirtualSocket, and specifies the protocol used by the VirtualSocket. The three parameters are not independent. Some address families restrict which protocols can be used with them, and often the socket type is implicit in the protocol. If the combination of address family, socket type, and protocol type results in an invalid VirtualSocket, a SocketException is thrown.
The AddressFamily enumeration defines the valid address families, the SocketType enumeration defines the valid socket types, and the ProtocolType enumeration defines the valid protocol types.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Receive(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Receives data from a connected VirtualSocket in a specific location of the receive buffer.
member.param: The storage location for received data.
member.returns: The number of bytes received.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: This overload only requires you to provide a receive buffer. The offset defaults to 0, size defaults to the buffer length, and the socketFlags value defaults to None.

The Blocking determines the behavior of this method when no incoming data is available. When false, a SocketException is thrown. When true, this method blocks and waits for data to arrive. For Stream Socket types, if the remote Socket was shut down gracefully, and all the data was received, this method immediately returns zero, regardless of the blocking state.

If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the message is larger than the size of the buffer parameter, buffer is filled with the first part of the message, and a SocketException is thrown. With unreliable protocols the excess data is lost; with reliable protocols, the data is retained by the service provider.

Note If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketFlags parameter, and the Socket is configured for in-line reception of out-of-band (OOB) data (using the OutOfBandInline option) and OOB data is available, then only OOB data is returned. When the Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but is not removed from the system buffer.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Receive(System.Byte[],System.Net.Sockets.SocketFlags)
member.summary: Receives data from a connected VirtualSocket in a specific location of the receive buffer.
member.param: The storage location for received data.
A bitwise combination of the values.
member.returns: The number of bytes received.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: This overload only requires you to provide a receive buffer and the necessary SocketFlags. The offset defaults to 0, and the size defaults to the buffer length.

The Blocking determines the behavior of this method when no incoming data is available. When false, a SocketException is thrown. When true, this method blocks and waits for data to arrive. For Stream Socket types, if the remote Socket was shut down gracefully, and all the data was received, this method immediately returns zero, regardless of the blocking state.

If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the message is larger than the size of the buffer parameter, buffer is filled with the first part of the message, and a SocketException is thrown. With unreliable protocols the excess data is lost; with reliable protocols, the data is retained by the service provider.

Note If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketFlags parameter, and the Socket is configured for in-line reception of out-of-band (OOB) data (using the OutOfBandInline option) and OOB data is available, then only OOB data is returned. When the Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but is not removed from the system buffer.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.ReceiveFrom(System.Byte[],System.Net.EndPoint@)
member.summary: Receives a datagram in a specific location in the data buffer and stores the endpoint.
member.param: The storage location for received data.
An , passed by reference, that represents the remote server.
member.returns: The number of bytes received.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: This overload only requires you to provide a receive buffer, and EndPoint representing the remote host. The offset defaults to 0. The size defaults to the buffer length and the socketFlags value defaults to None.

If you use a connectionless protocol, the remoteEP parameter contains the EndPoint associated with the Socket that sent the data. If you use a connection-oriented protocol, remoteEP is left unchanged. You must set the LocalEndPoint property before calling this method. When no incoming data is available, and the Blocking property is false, a SocketException is thrown. When Blocking is true, this method blocks and waits for data to arrive. For Stream Socket types, if the remote Socket was shut down gracefully, and all data was received, this method immediately returns zero, regardless of the blocking state.

If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the message is larger than the size of the buffer parameter, then buffer is filled with the first part of the message, and a SocketException is thrown. With unreliable protocols the excess data is lost; with reliable protocols, the data is retained by the service provider.

When the OutOfBand flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter and the Socket is configured for in-line reception of out-of-band (OOB) data (using OutOfBandInline) and OOB data is available, only OOB data is returned. When the SocketFlags. Peek flag is specified as the socketFlags parameter, available data is copied into the receive buffer but not removed from the system buffer.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Send(System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sends data to a connected VirtualSocket, starting at the indicated location in the data.
member.param: The data to be sent.
member.returns: The number of bytes sent to the VirtualSocket.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the socket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: Use Send for connection-oriented protocols only. For connectionless protocols, either use SendTo or call Connect first, and then call Send. This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer. The offset defaults to 0, the size defaults to the buffer length, and SocketFlags value defaults to None.
You must set the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance before calling this method.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Send(System.Byte[],System.Net.Sockets.SocketFlags)
member.summary: Sends data to a connected VirtualSocket, starting at the indicated location in the data.
member.param: The data to be sent.
A bitwise combination of the SocketFlags values.
member.returns: The number of bytes sent to the VirtualSocket.
member.exception: is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the socket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: Use Send for connection-oriented protocols only. For connectionless protocols, either use SendTo or call Connect first, and then call Send.
This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer and SocketFlags. The offset defaults to 0, and the size parameter defaults to the buffer length.
You must set the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance before calling this method.

If you specify the DontRoute flag as the socketflags parameter, the data you are sending will not be routed. If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketflags parameter, only out-of-band (OOB) data is sent.
If you set the Blocking property to true, and buffer space is not available within the underlying protocol, this method blocks.
If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the size of the buffer is greater than the maximum message size of the underlying protocol, no data is sent and Socket will throw a SocketException.

remarks.p: Use Send for connection-oriented protocols only. For connectionless protocols, either use SendTo or call Connect first, and then call Send.
This overload gives you the flexibility to specify the Send starting position in the data buffer, the number bytes you are sending, and the necessary SocketFlags.
You must set the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance before calling this method.

If you specify the DontRoute flag as the socketflags parameter, the data you are sending will not be routed. If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketflags parameter, only out-of-band (OOB) data is sent.
If you set the Blocking property to true, and buffer space is not available within the underlying protocol, this method blocks.
If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the size of the buffer is greater than the maximum message size of the underlying protocol, no data is sent and Socket will throw a SocketException.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.SendTo(System.Byte[],System.Net.EndPoint)
member.summary: Sends data to a specific endpoint, starting at the indicated location in the data.
member.param: The data to be sent.
The representing the destination location for the data.
member.returns: The number of bytes sent.
member.exception:
is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
-or-
The remoteEP parameter is a null reference (Nothing).
An operating system error occurs while accessing the socket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: If you are using a connection-oriented protocol or a connected Socket using a connectionless protocol, remoteEP overrides the endpoint specified in RemoteEndPoint. If you are using an unconnected Socket with a connectionless protocol, this method sets the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance to a value determined by the protocol. You must subsequently receive data on the LocalEndPoint. This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer, and the remote EndPoint. The offset defaults to 0. The size defaults to the buffer length, and SocketFlags value defaults to None.

remarks.p: If you are using a connection-oriented protocol or a connected Socket using a connectionless protocol, remoteEP overrides the endpoint specified in RemoteEndPoint. If you are using an unconnected Socket with a connectionless protocol, this method sets the LocalEndPoint property of the current instance to a value determined by the protocol. You must subsequently receive data on the LocalEndPoint.
This overload only requires you to provide a data buffer, SocketFlags, and the remote EndPoint. The offset defaults to 0, and size defaults to the buffer length.

Note If you specify the DontRoute flag as the socketflags parameter, the data you are sending will not be routed. If you specify the OutOfBand flag as the socketflags parameter, only out-of-band (OOB) data is sent. If you set the Blocking property to true, and buffer space is not available within the underlying protocol, this method blocks. If you are using a message-oriented Socket, and the size of buffer is greater than the maximum message size of the underlying protocol, no data is sent and Socket will throw a SocketException. If you are using a connection-oriented Socket, remoteEp is ignored.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.SetSocketOption(System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionLevel,System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName,System.Byte[])
member.summary: Sets the specified option to the specified value.
member.param: A value.
A value.
A byte array representing the value of the option.
member.exception: The VirtualSocket has been closed.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.
member.remarks:
Socket options determine the behavior of the current Socket. Use this overload to set those Socket options that require a byte array as an option value.
Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.SetSocketOption(System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionLevel,System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName,System.Int32)
member.summary: Sets the specified option to the specified value.
member.param: A value.
A value.
A value of the option.
member.exception: The VirtualSocket has been closed.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.
member.remarks:
Socket options determine the behavior of the current Socket. For an option with a Boolean data type, specify a nonzero value to enable the option, and a zero value to disable the option. For an option with an integer data type, specify the appropriate value. Socket options are grouped by level of protocol support.
Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.SetSocketOption(System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionLevel,System.Net.Sockets.SocketOptionName,System.Object)

is a null reference (Nothing in Visual Basic).
member.remarks:
Socket options determine the behavior of the current Socket. Use this overload to set those Socket options that require anything other than an integer or Boolean as an option value. For example, to set the Linger option, you must create an instance of LingerOption and pass it to SetSocketOption as the optionvalue parameter.
Windows 98, Windows NT 4.0 Platform Note: You must call the Bind method before using AddMembership as the optionName parameter.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Shutdown(System.Net.Sockets.SocketShutdown)
member.summary: Disables sends and receives on a VirtualSocket.
member.param: The value specifying the operation that will no longer be allowed.
member.exception: An error occurs while closing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

remarks.p: Setting how to Send, specifies that subsequent calls to Send are not allowed. With TCP sockets, a FIN will be sent after all data is sent and acknowledged by the receiver.

Setting how to Receive, specifies that subsequent calls to Receive are not allowed. This has no effect on lower protocol layers. For TCP sockets, the connection is reset if data is waiting to be received or if more data arrives after the Socket is disabled. For UDP sockets, datagrams are accepted and queued.
Setting how to Both disables both sends and receives as described above.
To finish closing the Socket, a call to Close must be made after the call to Shutdown. You should not attempt to reuse the Socket.

member.summary: Holds the value of the property.

member.value: true if the VirtualSocket will block; otherwise, false. The default is true.

The VirtualSocket has been closed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.AddressFamily
member.summary: Gets the address family of the VirtualSocket.
member.value: One of the values.
member.remarks: AddressFamily specifies the addressing scheme that an instance of the VirtualSocket class can use. This property is read-only and is set when the VirtualSocket is created.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Available
member.summary: Gets the amount of data that has been received from the network and is available to be read.
member.value: The number of bytes of data that has been received from the network and are available to be read.
member.remarks: If you are using a Stream VirtualSocket type, the available data is generally the total amount of data queued on the current instance. If you are using a message-oriented VirtualSocket type such as Dgram, the available data is the first message in the input queue.
member.exception: An error occurs while accessing the VirtualSocket.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Connected
member.summary: Gets a value indicating whether a VirtualSocket is connected to a remote resource.
member.value: true if the VirtualSocket is connected to a remote resource; otherwise, false.
member.remarks:
Gets the connection state of the VirtualSocket. This property will return the latest known state of the VirtualSocket. When it returns false, the VirtualSocket was either never connected, or no longer connected. When it returns true, the VirtualSocket was connected at the time of the last I/O operation.
Note There is no guarantee that the VirtualSocket is still Connected even though Connected returns true.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.Handle
member.summary: Gets the operating system handle for the VirtualSocket.
member.value: An representing the operating system handle for the VirtualSocket.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.LocalEndPoint
member.summary: Gets the local endpoint.
member.value: The local endpoint that the VirtualSocket is using for communications.
member.remarks: The LocalEndPoint property contains the network connection information associated with the local network device. LocalEndPoint is set by calling the Bind method.
member.exception: An error occurs while reading the property.
The VirtualSocket has been closed.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.ProtocolType
member.summary: Gets the protocol type of the VirtualSocket.
member.value: One of the values.
member.remarks: ProtocolType is set when the VirtualSocket is created, and specifies the protocol used by that VirtualSocket.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.VirtualSocket.RemoteEndPoint
member.summary: Gets the remote endpoint.
member.value: The remote endpoint that the VirtualSocket is using for communications.
member.remarks: The RemoteEndPoint property gets the network connection information associated with the remote host. RemoteEndPoint is set by VirtualSocket methods that establish a connection to a remote host.
member.exception: An error occurs while reading the property.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureSocket.QueueRenegotiate
member.summary: Queues a renegotiation request.
member.exception: An operating system error occurs while accessing the SecureSocket.
member.remarks: Use the QueueRenegotiate function with caution. Some SSL/TLS clients or server do not support renegotiation. For instance, requesting a renegotiation in the middle of sending a HTTP request to a MS IIS server causes the connection to be shut down. Renegotiations should only be used when a small private key [512 bits] is used and the connection is active for a long period of time.

If SSL or TLS is not used, this property returns SslAlgorithms.NONE.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.LingerState
member.summary: Gets or sets information about the sockets linger time.
member.value: A LingerOption.
member.remarks: This property controls the length of time that the underlying Socket will remain open after a call to Close, when data remains to be sent. If the Enabled property of the LingerOption is true, then data will continue to be sent to the network with a time out of LingerOption.LingerTime seconds. Once the data is sent, or if the time-out expires, the connection is closed and any unsent data is lost. If the Enabled property of the LingerOption is false , then the connection will close, even if data remains to be sent.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.NoDelay
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that enables a delay when send or receive buffers are not full.
member.value: true to disable a delay, otherwise false.
member.remarks: When NoDelay is false, TCP does not send a packet over the network until it has collected a significant amount of outgoing data. Because of the amount of overhead in a TCP segment, sending small amounts of data would be very inefficient. However, situations do exist where you might want to send very small amounts of data or expect immediate responses from each packet you send. Your decision should weigh the relative importance of network efficiency versus application requirements.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.ReceiveBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the receive buffer.
member.value: The size of the receive buffer, in bytes.
member.remarks: The ReceiveBufferSize property gets or sets the number of bytes that you are expecting to store in the receive buffer for each read operation.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.ReceiveTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time a will wait to receive data once initiated.
member.value: The time-out value of the connection in milliseconds.
member.remarks: The ReceiveTimeout property determines the amount of time a SecureTcpClient will wait to receive data after a read is initiated. This time is measured in milliseconds. The underlying Socket will throw a SocketException if a read is initiated, and the ReceiveTimeout expires.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.SendBufferSize
member.summary: Gets or sets the size of the send buffer.
member.value: The size of the send buffer, in bytes.
member.remarks: The SendBufferSize property gets or sets the number of bytes to store in the send buffer for each send operation.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.SendTimeout
member.summary: Gets or sets the amount of time a SecureTcpClient will wait to receive confirmation after you initiate a send.
member.value: The send time-out value, in milliseconds.
member.remarks: After you initiate a send, the underlying returns the number of bytes actually sent to the host. The SendTimeout property determines the amount of time a TcpClient will wait before receiving the number of bytes returned by the SecureSocket class. The underlying SecureSocket will throw a SocketException if a send is initiated and the SendTimeout expires.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.Client
member.summary: Gets or sets the underlying .
member.value: The underlying Network Socket.
member.remarks: SecureTcpClient creates a SecureSocket to send and receive data over a network. Classes deriving from SecureTcpClient can use this property to get or set this SecureSocket. Use the underlying SecureSocket returned from Client, if you require access beyond that which SecureTcpClient provides. You can also use Client to set the underlying SecureSocket to an existing SecureSocket. This might be useful if you want to take advantage of the simplicity of SecureTcpClient using a pre-existing SecureSocket.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.Active
member.summary: Gets or set a value that indicates whether a connection has been made.
member.value: true if the connection has been made; otherwise, false.
member.remarks: Classes deriving from SecureTcpClient can use this property to keep track of the underlying connection state.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.CleanedUp
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that indicates whether the underlying SecureSocket has been closed or not.
member.value: true if the underlying has been closed, false otherwise.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpClient.DataStream
member.summary: Gets or sets the underlying associated with this SecureTcpClient.
member.value: An instance of the SecureNetworkStream class.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpListener.AcceptSocket
member.summary: Accepts a pending connection request.
member.returns: A used to send and receive data.
member.exception: The listener has not been started with a call to Start.
An operating system error occurs while accessing the SecureSocket.
Unable to create the SSPI credentials.
member.remarks:
AcceptSocket returns a SecureSocket that you can use to send and receive data. This SecureSocket is initialized with the IP address and port number of the remote machine. You can use any of the Send and Receive methods available in the Socket class to communicate with the remote machine.
Note When you finish using the Socket, be sure to call its Close method.
Note If your application is relatively simple, consider using the AcceptTcpClient method rather than AcceptSocket. SecureTcpClient provides you with simple methods for sending and receiving data over a network.

member.name: M:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpListener.AcceptTcpClient
member.summary: Accepts a pending connection request.
member.returns: A SecureTcpClient used to send and receive data.
member.exception: The listener has not been started with a call to Start.
An operating system error occurs while accessing the SecureSocket.
Unable to create the SSPI credentials.
member.remarks:
AcceptTcpClient returns a SecureTcpClient that you can use to send and receive data. Use SecureTcpClient.GetStream to obtain the underlying SecureNetworkStream of the SecureTcpClient. SecureNetworkStream inherits from Stream, which provides a rich collection of methods and properties for network communications.
Note When you are through with the returned SecureTcpClient, be sure to call it's Close method.
Note If you want greater flexibility than a SecureTcpClient offers, consider using AcceptSocket.

member.name: P:Xceed.Utils.Security.Ssl.SecureTcpListener.Server
member.summary: Gets the underlying .
member.value: An instance of the SecureSocket class that provides the underlying network socket.
member.remarks:
SecureTcpListener creates a SecureSocket to listen for incoming client connection requests. Classes deriving from SecureTcpListener can use this property to get this Socket. Use the underlying SecureSocket returned by the Server property if you require access beyond that which SecureTcpListener provides.
Note Server only returns the SecureSocket used to listen for incoming client connection requests. Use the AcceptSocket method to accept a pending connection request and obtain a SecureSocket for sending and receiving data. You can also use the AcceptTcpClient method to accept a pending connection request and obtain a SecureTcpClient for sending and receiving data.

member.name: T:Xceed.Ftp.AsyncFtpClient
member.summary: This class provides you with access to asynchronous FTP functionalities. GUI applications should always use the AsyncFtpClient class since the library uses multiple threads. When using the class, the user is prone to encounter timeout errors since the library may be trying to generate events on the main UI thread through a message, but the application is blocked in a method call and not pumping messages.

remarks.para: Xceed FTP for .NET is a highly multi-threaded library that uses asynchronous operations on sockets and network streams to allow fast and fluent execution. This results in most events being called from a different thread than the one that called the initiating method.

When building a GUI application using System.Windows.Forms, you must always make sure to access UI elements (controls and forms) from the main thread since all those controls have thread-affinity for the main STA thread. This is done using Control.Invoke or Control.BeginInvoke.

If you use the class, subscribe to an event and call a method, your main UI thread will be blocked in that method call and will not pump messages. The event you subscribe to will be raised on a different thread, so Control.Invoke must be called to make any changes to the user interface of your application. This, however, causes another problem: your main UI thread is not pumping messages, and Control.Invoke will freeze until the method call times out. If you use Control.BeginInvoke, it will not freeze, but the invocation will get through after the method returns: only then will your UI be updated.

The safe and correct way of using Xceed FTP for .NET in a GUI application is to use the AsyncFtpClient class, call asynchronous methods (those that start with "Begin"), provide callbacks and call the corresponding "End" method in them, or manually pump messages while waiting for completion and then call the corresponding "End" method.

If you do not want to have to call Control.Invoke to update the UI in the callbacks, you can set the AsyncFtpClient's property to your form (or any other control that implements the ISynchronizeInvoke interface) to automatically do it for you. However, in order for the SynchronizingObject to work, your application must be pumping messages, either explicitly while waiting for completion (Application.DoEvents), or by not calling any blocking methods and returning control to your application's main loop (Application.Run in Main).
There are two suggested ways to use AsyncFtpClient in a GUI application:

member.name: T:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient
member.summary: This class provides you with quick and easy access to FTP functionalities in the same style as the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

remarks.para: GUI applications should always use the class since the library uses multiple threads. When using the FtpClient class, the user is prone to encounter timeout errors since the library may be trying to generate events on the main UI thread through a message, but the application is blocked in a method call and not pumping messages.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.Connect(System.String)
member.summary: Connects the FTP client to an FTP server on port 21.
member.param: The hostname of the FTP server to connect to. An IP address can also be used.

para.note: If the IP address contains a port (ie.: 192.168.0.42:2121) then the FTP client will connect on the specified port rather than port 21 (default).

remarks.para: This method will only connect you to the FTP server. Once connected, you must call the method to log-in to the FTP server.

member.exception: Cannot perform the requested operation because the FTP client is in an invalid state.
An error reply was returned by the FTP server.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.Authenticate(Xceed.Ftp.AuthenticationMethod,Xceed.Ftp.VerificationFlags,Xceed.Ftp.Certificate,Xceed.Ftp.DataChannelProtection)
member.summary: Authenticates and encrypts the current FTP connection.
member.param: The authentication method used to connect to the FTP server.
The verification flags used to verify the FTP server's certificate.
The FTP client's certificate.
How the data channels will be protected.

remarks.para: The method that requires an authentication method, verification flags and a client certificate can be used in the case where the FTP server does not allow authentication after the connection has been established.
If the FTP server requires a certificate or the one provided was rejected, the will be raised. When the FTP server's certificate is received and verified, the event will be raised.
The Authenticate method will send the AUTH and PROT commands to the FTP server.

The Authenticate method will send the AUTH and PROT commands to the FTP server.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.GetCurrentFolder
member.summary: Retrieves the current working folder of the FTP server.
member.returns: A string representing the FTP server's current folder. The path returned is an absolute path that can be used with the to go directly to this folder regardless of the current working folder.

remarks.para: The FTP server's current working folder is used by the FTP server as the base folder from which to perform file operations such as obtaining folder contents, receiving, sending and deleting files, changing the current folder, etc. It can be changed using the and methods.
The GetCurrentFolder method will send the PWD command to the FTP server.
This method is the equivalent of the CurrentFolder property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ChangeCurrentFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Changes the current working folder of the FTP server.
member.param: The new current working folder. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!

remarks.para: Both relative and absolute paths can be provided to the ChangeCurrentFolder method to change the FTP server's current working folder, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The method should be used in the case where you want the parent folder to be the new current working folder.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.
The ChangeCurrentFolder method will send the CWD command to the FTP server.

Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.
The CreateFolder method will send the MKD command to the FTP server.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.DeleteFolder(System.String)
member.summary: Deletes a folder from the FTP server.
member.param: The name of the folder to delete. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!

remarks.para: By default, the folder will be deleted from the current working folder. If you want to delete the folder from another location, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.

para.note: This overload of the DeleteFolder method requires that the folder be empty in order to delete it. Some FTP servers will allow folders that contain child items to be deleted, therefore, it is possible that calling this overload of the DeleteFolder method will delete a folder even if it contains child items.

remarks.para: The DeleteFolder method will send the RMD command to the FTP server.
This method is the equivalent of the RemoveFolder method of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.DeleteFolder(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Deletes a folder, and optionally each item in the folder, from the FTP server.
member.param: The name of the folder to delete. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!
if each item in the folder should also be deleted; otherwise.

remarks.para: By default, the folder will be deleted from the current working folder. If you want to delete the folder from another location, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.

note.b: Some FTP servers will allow folders that contain child items to be deleted, therefore, it is possible that calling this overload of the DeleteFolder method with its parameter set to will still delete each item in the folder (including the folder).

remarks.para: The DeleteFolder method will send the RMD command and optionally the PWD, CWD, TYPE, PASV or PORT and LIST commands to the FTP server.
This method is the equivalent of the RemoveFolder method of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.GetFolderContents(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves the contents of the current working folder.
member.param: The file mask of the remote files to retrieve. This parameter can include a filtering mask to limit the files that are retrieved. For example, if is specified, the entire contents of the current working folder will be retrieved. If "*.txt" is used, all the files in the current working folder that have the TXT extension will be retrieved. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!
member.returns: A reference to an collection containing objects each representing a file matched by .

remarks.para: If you want to retrieve the contents of another folder, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.
The listing lines can be manually parsed or modified via the event.

para.note: If you would prefer to receive an unprocessed list of items, you can use the method instead.
The TYPE command will be sent regardless of the value of the property when calling the GetFolderContents method.

remarks.para: The GetFolderContents method will send the LIST and PASV or PORT and TYPE commands to the FTP server.
This method is the equivalent of the GetFolderContents and ListFolderContents methods of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.GetRawFolderContents(System.String,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Retrieves an unprocessed, clear text list representing the contents of the current working folder as sent by the FTP server and indicates if the entire listing or only filenames should be retrieved.
member.param: The file mask of the remote files to retrieve. This parameter can can include a filtering mask to limit the files that are retrieved. If "*.txt" is used, all the files in the current working folder that have the TXT extension will be retrieved. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!
if only filenames should be retrieved; otherwise.
member.returns: A reference to a collection containing a list of unprocessed strings each representing a file matched by . For example: "07-25-03 11:46AM 101 001fdf63.xml". Of course, the format of the strings returned by the FTP server can vary from server to server.

remarks.para: If you want to retrieve the contents of another folder, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.

If is set to , the NLST command will be sent to the FTP server and only the name of the items will be returned.If is set to , the LIST command will be sent to the FTP server all the available information will be returned.

para.note: If you would prefer to receive a processed list of items, you can use the method instead.
The TYPE command will be sent regardless of the value of the property when calling the GetRawFolderContents method.

remarks.para: The GetRawFolderContents method will send the LIST or NLST and PASV or PORT and TYPE commands to the FTP server.

The byte offset (of the remote file) at which to start receiving data from the remote file. If is , the remote file will be appended to the end of the local file no matter what the value of . Therefore, to implement a real resume procedure, the size of the local file must be specified in and must be set to .
The path and filename of the file as it will be stored on the local system.
if the file should append itself to the local file if it already exists; if the local file should be overwritten.

remarks.para: By default, the file will be received from the current working folder. If you want to receive the file from another location, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.
The ReceiveFile method will send the RETR, REST and PORT or PASV commands and optionally the TYPE command to the FTP server.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ReceiveMultipleFiles(System.String,System.String,System.Boolean,System.Boolean)
member.summary: Receives the files that match the provided file mask from the current working folder and stores them on the local system in the specified folder.
member.param: The file mask of the remote files to receive. This parameter can include a filtering mask to limit the files that are received. For example, if is specified, the entire contents of the current working folder will be received. If "*.txt" is used, all the files in the current working folder that have the TXT extension will be received. Some FTP servers may be case-sensitive!
The path and name of the local folder where the files will be stored.
if the files in child folders should also be received; otherwise.
if the remote directory structure should be recreated on the local machine; otherwise.

remarks.para: If a folder is specified in , for example "MyFiles/*" and is set to , the "MyFiles" folder will be recreated locally in . If only a file mask is specified in , the files/folders will be recreated directly in .

By default, the files that match the provided file mask will be received from the current working folder. If you want to receive the files from another location, you could use the and/or methods to change the current working folder. Absolute paths can also be provided, however some FTP servers might not support absolute paths and different server types may have different ways of representing absolute paths.
The current working folder can be retrieved via the method.

para.note: By default, if an error occurs during the multiple-file transfer, the entire operation will be aborted. To change this behavior, the event must be handled and its property set to either Retry or Ignore.
The TYPE command will be sent regardless of the value of the property when calling the ReceiveMultipleFiles method during the initial listing phase.

remarks.para: The ReceiveMultipleFiles method will send the LIST, RETR, PASV or PORT, TYPE, PWD and CWD commands to the FTP server.

member.name: M:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.SendCustomCommand(System.String)
member.summary: Sends a custom command to the FTP server.
member.param: The command to send to the FTP server.
member.returns: The reply received from the FTP server in response to the custom command.

remarks.para: The SendCustomCommand method is used to send FTP commands. This means that commands you enter using the Windows command-line FTP (such as "dir", "put" or "debug") are not the commands that are actually sent to the FTP server. Although these commands might be recognized by some FTP servers, they are not guaranteed to work!.
When sending a custom FTP command, the local folder separator character will not be replaced by the to allow the local folder separator character to be sent "as is".

Not all commands are supported by all FTP servers. In order to determine which commands are supported, you can use the SendCustomCommand method to send the "HELP" command. For example: ftp.SendCustomCommand( "HELP" );.

para.note: The SendCustomCommand method does not support custom commands that require a data connection such as STOR (), RETR (), NLST and LIST (), etc.

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent of the SendCommand method of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.exception: Cannot perform the requested operation because the FTP client is in an invalid state.
An error reply was returned by the FTP server.
An I/O error has occurred.
A fatal FTP-specific error has occurred..

remarks.para: The Abort method will send the ABOR command to the FTP server.
This method is the equivalent of the Abort property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

para.note: Any data connection will be disconnected before reading the reply to the Abort (ABOR) command.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.PassiveTransfer
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value indicating if the FTP client should initiate the data connection rather than the FTP server.
member.value: if the FTP client should initiate the data connection; otherwise. By default, this property is set to .

remarks.para: If set to , the PASV command will be sent to the FTP server rather than the PORT command resulting in the FTP server "listening" on a data port (other than its default) and waiting for a data connection to be established by the FTP client. If set to , the PORT command will be sent and the FTP client will be listening for an incoming data connection. The FTP server will establish the data connection upon receipt of a transfer command.
The reply to the PASV command includes the host and port address the FTP server is listening on.

para.note: If you are having issues connecting or sending and receiving files to and from a server, try setting the PassiveTransfer property to .

remarks.para: This property is the equivalent of the PassiveMode property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.RepresentationType
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating how the data is transferred to and from the FTP server.
member.value: An value indicating how the data is transferred to and from the FTP server. By default, this property is set to RepresentationType.Binary.

remarks.para: If set to RepresentationType.Binary (default), the data will be sent/received as contiguous bits which are packed into the 8-bit transfer bytes. If set to RepresentationType.Ascii, it will be sent/received using the standard 8-bit NVT-ASCII representation.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.PreAllocateStorage
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value indicating if the FTP server must reserve enough space before a file is sent.
member.value: if the FTP server must reserve space before a file is sent; otherwise. By default, this property is set to .

remarks.para: If set to , the "ALLO file_size" FTP command will be sent to the FTP server to allocate sufficient space before the file is sent.
This property is the equivalent of the AllocateStorage property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ListingParsers
member.summary: Gets a collection of objects that are used to parse the lines returned by calls to various methods.
member.value: A collection containing a list of objects that are used to parse the lines returned by calls to the , and methods.

remarks.para: By default, the FtpClient class provides line parsers for AS400, DOS (Windows), UNIX and VMS FTP servers. To manually parse list lines received from the FTP server, you can use the event.

para.note: If you want to support other FTP servers and provide your own line parser, you will need to create a class that derives from the class and add it to the ListingParsers collection.

remarks.para: This property can be considered to be the equivalent of the ListParsingFlags property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.TraceWriter
member.summary: Gets or sets the which will trace the connection/deconnection process as well as the commands and replies sent to and received from the FTP server.
member.value: A reference to a which will trace the connection/deconnection process as well as the commands and replies sent to and received from the FTP server. By default this property is set to therefore no tracing is done.

para.note: The FTP client will not dispose/close the writer.

remarks.para: This method is the equivalent of the CommandLogFilename property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.State

member.value: A value representing the current state of the FTP client.

remarks.para: This property is the equivalent of the CurrentState property of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ServerAddress
member.summary: Gets the IP address and port to which the FTP client is connected.
member.value: A reference to an object representing the IP address and port to which the FTP client is connected. Can be if the FTP client is not connected to an FTP server.

remarks.para: The IP address of the FTP server can be retreived via the property while the port can be retrieved via the property.
This property can be considered to be the equivalent of the ServerAddress and ServerPort properties of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.HostName
member.summary: Gets the host name used to connect, or an empty string if not connected.
member.value: A string representing the host name. If the connection was made with an IPEndPoint, a dotted format IP address will be returned.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.SendTypeCommand
member.summary: Gets or sets a boolean value indicating if the TYPE command should be sent before initiating a file transfer.
member.value: if the TYPE command should be sent before initiating a file transfer; otherwise. By default, this property is set to .

para.note: The TYPE command will be sent regardless of the value of the SendTypeCommand property when calling the , or method (when retrieving a remote folder's listing).

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.Timeout
member.summary: Gets or sets a value, in seconds, indicating after what period of time an FTP operation should timeout.
member.value: A value, in seconds, representing the period of time after which an FTP operation should timeout. By default, this property is set to 30 seconds.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.LocalAddress
member.summary: Gets or sets the local IP address and port from which the FTP client is connected.
member.value: A reference to an object representing the local IP address and port from which the FTP client is connected. If 0 (default) is specified for the port, a random port will be used. Can return if the FTP client is not connected to an FTP server. Can be set to (default) to use the default network adapter.

remarks.para: Normally this property can be ignored, however if your client machine has more than one network card, the IP address of the card to use can be specified via this property. IPAddress.Any (default) can also be used to let the operating system decide which network card to use.
The IP address of the FTP client can be retreived via the property while the port can be retrieved via the property.
Setting this property when already connected only affects the next connection.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.LocalDataAddress
member.summary: Gets or sets the IP address and port of the client-side data connection to use in subsequent data connections. If is , this property represents the address of the client-side listening socket waiting for the servers data connection request.
member.value: If , .Address + random port (0) will be used. If LocalAddress.Address is IPAddress.Any, LocalAddress.Address + LocalDataAddress.Port will be used.

remarks.para: Normally this property can be ignored, however if your client machine has more than one network card, the IP address of the card to use can be specified via this property. IPAddress.Any (default) can also be used to let the operating system decide which network card to use.
The IP address of the FTP client can be retreived via the property while the port can be retrieved via the property.
Setting this property when already connected only affects the next connection.

member.name: P:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ServerFolderSeparator
member.summary: Gets or sets the FTP server's folder separator character.
member.value: A char representing the FTP server's folder separator character. By default, '/'.

remarks.para: All methods will automatically change the local system's folder separator character (represented by ) to the ServerFolderSeparator character and vice-versa when the method returns. Listing lines will also contain the modified folder separator character.
If you do not want the folder separator characters to be modified, you can set the ServerFolderSeparator property to .

para.note: Only standard ASCII chars are permitted.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ParsingListingLine
member.summary: Raised when a listing line is received from the FTP server.

remarks.para: If e.Valid is when the event is raised, at least one parser succeeded in parsing the listing line and e.Item has been filled with the parsed information. To filter (remove) an item from the listing set e.Valid to . The content of e.Item can also be modified if you want to change the item's information.
If e.Valid is when the event is raised, none of the parsers succeeded in parsing the listing line. In this case you can provide your own parsing, fill e.Item and set e.Valid to .
Calls to the , and methods will raise this event.
This event is the equivalent of the ParsingListLine event of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.CommandSent
member.summary: Raised once for every command sent to the FTP server.

remarks.para: To be notified when a reply is received from the FTP server, subscribe to the event.
This event is the equivalent of the LoggingCommandLine event of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.ReplyReceived
member.summary: Raised once for each reply received from the FTP server. If a reply contains multiple lines, they will be received as a group.

remarks.para: To be notified when a command is sent to the FTP server, subscribe to the event.
This event is the equivalent of the LoggingCommandLine event of the ActiveX version of the Xceed FTP Library.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.Disconnected
member.summary: Raised when the method is called as well as when the connection is terminated by the FTP server.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.FileTransferStatus
member.summary: Raised for every 4Kb sent or received during a file transfer.

para.note: When receiving files with the method, some FTP servers will not provide the size of the file currently being received and therefore, some values of the will be 0. If you require these particular statistics, you can use the method instead of the method. The ReceiveMultipleFiles method requests a complete listing from the FTP server before receiving any files. The FTP client therefore obtains the file sizes of each file being received and can then provide these statistics during the FileTransferStatus event. If you use this technique, keep in mind that the receive operation will be slightly slower (due to the extra listing operation) and that it will not be possible to change the local filename of the file.

member.name: E:Xceed.Ftp.FtpClient.MultipleFileTransferError
member.summary: Raised when an error occurs while transferring multiple files to or from the FTP server to determine what action should be taken.

remarks.para: This event can only be raised by the or methods.

para.note: Other methods of the FTP client must not be called in this event handler! For example, cannot be called to delete an existing file so that the file transfer (for that particular file) can be retried.

The current working folder can be retrieved via the / methods.
The listing lines can be manually parsed or modified via the event.

para.note: If you would prefer to receive an unprocessed list of items, you can use the / methods instead.
The TYPE command will be sent regardless of the value of the property when calling the BeginGetFolderContents method.

When using a , the is provided as a parameter. You should call in that callback. When NOT providing a callback, you should keep the returned IAsyncResult and call EndGetFolderContents with it when ready to complete. In this later case, the call to EndGetFolderContents may block until the operation completes.

The byte offset (of the remote file) at which to start receiving data from the remote file. If is , the remote file will be appended to the end of the local file no matter what the value of .
